pullRequest.body:
When dealing with a function `f : Π i, α i` depending on many variables, some operations may get rid of the dependency on some variables (see `Function.updateFinset` or `MeasureTheory.lmarginal` for example). However considering this new function as having a different domain can lead to tedious writing.

On the other hand one wants to be able for example to call some function constant with respect to some variables and be able to infer this when applying transformations mentioned above. This PR introduces the predicate `DependsOn f s`, which states that if `x` and `y` coincide over the set `s`, then `f x = f y`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

:v: EtienneC30 can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks!
bors merge
bors d+
bors d+

This lemma makes it seem like `DependsOn` doesn't need to exist, since it's just a very special case of `Function.FactorsThrough`. What do we gain by adding this new predicate that can be easily written in terms of existing ones?

I think this predicate is very natural, and it makes more sense as a hypothesis in lemmas than a `FactorsThrough` hypothesis. I agree we do not gain much in use compared to a lemma `factorsThrough_restrict_iff`, but stating a lemma: "If this function only depends on those variables then ..." sounds much more natural to me than "If this function factors through the restriction to ...". It also seems to me to be a "canonical" (not sure about the word) specialization of `FactorsThrough`, i.e. something we often use in paper maths without explicitly referring to factorization. In particular I don't think we often rewrite a function `f` as `g ∘ r` (if `r` is the restriction), while we do so in other cases (the example that comes to my mind is factorization through the norm).

Thus in my opinion it is a specialization of `FactorsThrough` which is worth having. However if this not a good enough reason, I can turn this PR into one adding lemmas about `FactorsThrough` and `restrict`.

Okay, that's convincing. My follow-up question then is, is this more natural than a predicate for the functions being independent of certain variables? That is, `IndepOf` stating that the function `f` is unchanged if you change the entries from `s` (which should be DependsOn the complement of s). I believe it is more natural, but it was also my experience that the latter shows up more when restricting in a marginal probability context.

I guess one might say that saying a function does not depend on some variables is more natural, in particular because "depends on" strictly speaking does not mean it does not depend on other variables.

What is not clear about this however is how you would state this in Lean? I remember when I created the predicate I had this idea that changing variables over some set does nothing, but this precisely means that I don't care about what happens to those variables, and so the predicate should rather mention the variables I do care about, which is why I made this version.

So I think in the end `IndepOf` will boil down to `∀ x y, (∀ i ∉ s, x i = y i) → f x = f y`, and I prefer to have `∈` instead of `∉`.

> So I think in the end IndepOf will boil down to ∀ x y, (∀ i ∉ s, x i = y i) → f x = f y, and I prefer to have ∈ instead of ∉.

Yes, I think you came to the same conclusion I did: it's just the complement of s. I'd say some of what you mentioned should be in the module doc or implementation note here though, since it's a natural question. Similarly about the distinction between depending on or "potentially depending on", which seems a natural source of confusion here.
I added implementation notes, tell me if it seems clear.
I agree this is not comfortable, but sometimes it is necessary: can we have the lemma that `DependsOn` is equivalent to the existence of this function?

```suggestion
as having a different domain with fewer points is not comfortable in Lean, as it requires the use
```
Could you emphasize the point you make above, that it might not really depend on all the variables in `s`, for instance it could be constant.

```suggestion
On the other hand one wants to be able for example to describe some function as constant with respect to
some variables, and be able to deduce this when applying transformations mentioned above.
This is why we introduce the predicate `DependsOn f s`, which states that if `x` and `y` coincide over
the set `s`, then `f x = f y`. This is equivalent to `Function.FactorsThrough f s.restrict`.
```

small nitpicks, which I think make this slightly more readable

```suggestion
that `f` does not depend at all on variables in `s`, for example if `f` is constant`. As a consequence, 
`DependsOn f univ` is always true, see `dependsOn_univ`.
```
I think the last point here doesn't oppose the earlier ones!

pullRequest.title: feat: introduce a predicate `DependsOn`
